title: Hatchy
author: Hatchy
content: NoteI don't know, if this is the right board to post this, but if it isn't then please someone suggest which or mod help me move it to the right section. I'm writing to raise awareness about a critical security threat that poses a significant risk to iOS users and probably other operating systems. Recently, a new malware called HVNC(Hidden Virtual Network Computer)  designed by some Russian hackers is being sold on the dark web for a staggering $60,000 price for a lifetime access. HVNC is a highly sophisticated malware with powerful phishing capabilities. Once it gains access to a device, it can be utilized to breach crypto wallets, potentially leading to the loss of funds or even complete control of your assets.This dangerous HVNC tool, discovered by cybersecurity firm Guardz, grants hackers full access to Apple systems, making it possible to steal personal information and cryptocurrencies. The creator of this malware is now selling it for around $100,000, and its existence poses a severe threat to our community's security.To protect ourselves, it is crucial to exercise extreme caution when accessing unknown websites, especially the dark web. ## For users of mobile wallets, it is strongly advised to avoid visiting such sites altogether due to the heightened risk of cybercriminals accessing your personal data.##In case you must access these websites, take every precaution possible. Use a secure connection or a "VPN" or opt to use a device that is entirely separate from your personal data to mitigate the risk.Remember that the safety of our digital assets and personal information is of utmost importance. Let us all remain vigilant and security-conscious to safeguard ourselves and the Bitcoin community from potential harm.Here's a source for full details: https://cryptonews.net/21394922/?utm_source=CryptoNews&utm_medium=app&utm_campaign=shared

comments.author: Z-tight
comments.body: Quote from: Hatchy on August 05, 2023, 10:08:41 AMRecently, a new malware called HVNC(Hidden Virtual Network Computer)  designed by some Russian hackers is being sold on the dark web for a staggering $60,000 price for a lifetime access. $60k is a lot of money, if what the seller is saying is true, then this malware is above the purchase of a regular cybercriminal. In the article you posted, it says that the seller has placed $100k in escrow as proof that the malware works as they said it will, the article doesn't state how the escrow was set up, so there is also a possibility that the seller could be a scammer.People are becoming more knowledgeable about cybercrimes, so buying this is even going to be risky for a criminal who can afford it, because you may not be able to recover your money. I don't care if people are scammed when they try to scam other people, but i care about the victims of scams, so it is important to be very careful about malwares and protect your coins and personal data, don't click on links that you are not sure of and double check everything when it is about your coins.

comments.author: DaveF
comments.body: From the article linked:QuoteThe HVNC tool only works on Macs running macOS Venture 13.2 or older softwareSo, you would have to be using a version of the OS that at this point is close to 6 months and 5 updates old.13.2.1 was released on Feb 13th (which fixed this vulnerability at least according to the article and Apple)13.3 was released on March 2713.3.1 was released on April 7th13.4 was released on May 14th13.4.1 was released on June 21st13.5 was released on July 24thWhat the hell are people doing storing funds on unpatched & unupdated machines.If this happened in late Feb to early April then OK, you wanted others to be sure that there were no major issues happening with the new OS builds.But now, sorry that's just being lazy. macOS is becoming a better target for criminals since so many people buy into the hype 'macs can't be hacked' and that just makes them a nice easy target for criminals.-Dave

comments.body: Cybercriminals have invested $60,000 to purchase a malware, so imagine how big their plans are. They may already be using this malware to attack their targeted victims, many crypto users may have already fallen victim. A crypto user always needs to be aware of cybersecurity, as cybercriminals target crypto users most of the time these days. So I think it is very important for crypto users to be careful now because these scammers will try to trap crypto users with this malware, and for this they will promote with various tempting offers so that inexperienced crypto users install this malware on their devices. Crypto users will give scammers full access to their devices and fall prey to scams.
